vaccineff 0.0.1

    Function to assign the outcome status or the vaccination status

    set_status.Rd

    This function generates a binary status column using the set of columns, passed through the variable col_names. This columns must contain the information of the outcomes or the vaccine dates. It generates a logical condition using the operators "&" or "|", and evaluates if the registers in the columns contain or not information. If the logical operator is "&", the function returns 1, only if all the columns contain information. On the other hand, if the logical operator is "|", it is enough to find one column with information. It is recommended to use this method when working with several outcomes or several vaccine doses. By default, it returns a binary column where 0 means no outcome or no vaccine and 1 means the opposite. However, it can also receive personalized options, e.g. c("v", "u") for vaccinated and unvaccinated.

    Usage

    set_status(data, col_names, operator = "&", status = c(1, 0))

    Arguments

    data

    dataset with at least one column to generate the status

    col_names

    name of the column containing the information for the status

    operator

    logical operator to evaluate the condition

    status

    binary set of status, e.g. c("v","u"). The first element of the vector must be the status when the condition is satisfied.

    Value

    status

    Examples

    if (FALSE) {
data("cohortdata")
cohortdata$vaccine_status <- set_status(
data = cohortdata,
col_names = c("vaccine_date_1", "vaccine_date_2"),
status = c("v", "u"))
}
